text: CLOSE SLOT В— the hand of General Nikolas Pherides  The General's hand spasmodically opens and closes around the of a sword which has been struck into the earth, point foremost as a support. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal his naked forearm and fro this forearm gush gouts of arterial blood. The blood fall into an enamel basin, Over this CLOSE SHOT VOICES can be heard.

Dead on the field, four thousand five hundred seventyВ—two of the enemy В— three thousand of our own men. Burial parties are already at work. We are assigning men from every company to clear the field,
(cutting in) Tell them to pour lime in the graves.

The CAMERA IS DRAWING BACK to reveal General Nikolas Pherides, the commander of a Greek army corps, seated beh a small table  His left hand is outstretched to the barberВ—surgeon who kneels at his side and is engaged in bleeding him,
(same tone) Enemy casualties estimated as nine thousand В—В— prisoners В—В—five hundred.

The CAMERA CONTINUES DRAWING BACK to disclose the entire on scene. Four Greek officers stand before the General. are great burly line officers; their uniform tunics open the neck, their caps on the back of their heads and their great sabres trailing along the ground. The third is a medical officer, Dr. Alexander Drossos. He is excessively neat and dandified in his uniform, with pinceВ—nez glasse perfectly straight on the bridge of his nose. The fourth an Adjutant, military enough in dress and bearing but wit great brigand's mustache and merry black eyes. At the General's right hand sits a young American, Oliver Davis, reporter for the New York Morning Globe. He is dressed in semiВ—uniform outfit which Richard Harding Davis populari breeches, leather leggings and a khaki tunic of military While the rest talk, he is busily scribbling on a pad, without paying the least attention to any of then. The second officer breaks in on the first officer's repor unable to restrain his enthusiasm longer
A greet battle В—В— a great victory!
MED. CLOSE SHOT В— General Pherides and Dr  Drossos.
(dryly) To be sure . Enough blood spilled to satisfy anyone -- (turning to the General) except General Nikolas Pherides. You're letting that fool drain your life away.
(looking up) Your father always prescribed it, and I'm alive to tell you so.
FULL SHOT В— the entire party inside the tent. In the meantime, the barber-surgeon has finished his work and is binding up the General's arm. He cinches the bandage tigh The doctor shrugs.
At least get a decent night's sleep. (smiling) Consider it a prescription from my father..

The General nods. The three officers and the Adjutant lea pausing at the tent flap to call back their "good nights" Hardly have they gone when the General rises from his cha and begins to pace the narrow floor of the tent; his shad walking with him on the side walls and ceiling. The young correspondent looks up and watches him. Finally, he speak MED. TWO SHOT - Oliver and the General.
Why not Take the doctor's advice? You're the hero of the battle of Corphon.
Hero?
(insistently) In the New York Morning Globe, the man who wins victory is always a hero. -
The General puts his hand on Oliver's arm.
Listen В—В—
Both men are silent in an attitude of listening - from outside can be heard distantly the screaming and groaning the wounded.
You know that sound, Oliver?
I heard the same sound at Ladysmith, at Nukden, Port Arthur.  What do you expect after a battle?
You were at those battles as a spectator В— В— I wonder if you can think what that sound might mean to me В—В— those men out there В—В— dead or dying В—В— by my order -- because I willed it so.

CLOSE TWO SHOT В— Oliver and the General. Oliver holds up lantern and tries to peer into the darkness. The General starts off and Oliver falls into step behind him. They pa sentry who salutes. Only the lighted lantern can be seen they go into the darkness.

The CAMERA in SET UP TO SHOOT PAST the heaped-up dead. Th only illumination is the lantern which Oliver carries, he the General pick their way between the dead. ANOTHER ASPECT of the battlefield - an ox cart loaded wit the dead, some of them tied to the rear axle by their nak legs. Two men, in the hooded coats worn by the infantry o the Balkan allies, are busy loading the cart. They look u astonished, as the General and Oliver pass. STILL ANOTHER ASPECT of the battlefield В— the General pa as if to search out his way and then starts off determine toward the left. Oliver takes two long strides to catch u with him. The CAMERA DOLLIES WITH them. Oliver lifts the lantern and gestures outward with it.
Over there, isn't it?
The General nods and starts off again rapidly, Oliver following.

The two men come over a rise of ground and stop at the ed of the beach. STOCK SHOT - The moon emerging from behind clouds EFFECT SHOT. In the foreground stand the two men. Before lies the sea and the Isle of the Dead. As they watch, beh them the moon emerges from the thick clouds and a great silver light floods over the sea. A little way from the beach, The Isle of the Dead stands from the glassyВ—calm, moonlit water. In the f.g. is a br Ionic column. There are a few flat stones at the water's edge, the remn of a quay which once reached out into the sea. Tied to ta stakes are two small row boats and a third lies half-buri in the sand. The CAMERA HOLDS until the General and Olive come into the scene and stand looking across the dark wat REVERSE CLOSE SHOT - Oliver watches the General, troubled his intention of crossing to the island.
Do you mind if I go with you?
There's no one there -В— nothing but the caves and the dead.
I'll only go as far as the shore and wait for you.
The General- makes a slight gesture of indifference and m forward.
MED. SHOT В— the General steps into one of the boats. Oli casts off the minter and puts the lantern down on the san
I'll leave this here to guide us back.
He jumps into the boat, picks up an oar, pushes off and starts to scull.

head_text.subj: EXT THE ISLE OF THE DEAD

text: The boat noses its bow onto the shelving beach. The men c out. Oliver pulls the boat a little farther onto the sand looks back toward the mainland.
LONG SHOT - The lantern is glowing at the water's edge. Suddenly it flickers and dies out.

head_text.subj: EXT THE ISLE OF THE DEAD

text: CLOSE SHOT В— Oliver, having seen the lantern fail, shive MED. TWO SHOT - Oliver and the General. On the edge of' t wall nearest thorn is a marble figure of Cerberus, the th headed dog which guards the dead. Two of the heads have b carved to represent sleeping heads; the third head glares toward the mainland with a sightless, unseeing, but ever watchful stare, Oliver takes the General's arm and draws attention to the statue.
Cerberus В—В— the watchdog. He guards the sleep of those who are buried here.
The two men walk forward into the towering shadows of the cypress trees, turning toward the left. They are lost to in the shadows. The CAMERA HOLDS ON Cerberus.

MED. FULL SHOT В— The General and Oliver come walking ont ledge before the crypt. They pause a moment while the Gen looks about as if to get his bearings, then he moves resolutely toward the crypt nearest. Oliver goes with him far as the doorway. MED. FULL SHOT - The doorway of the crypt. At the doorway Oliver stops.
(almost whispering) I'll wait here for you.

The General nods, removes his hat and goes into the crypt is lost in the darkness. Oliver tries to peer in after hi The opaque blackness prevents him seeing anything. He relaxes, pulls a square cardboard box of cigarettes from coat pocket, selects one, puts it in his mouth and is fumbling for a match when suddenly the General reВ—appear Oliver looks at him in astonishment.
She is not there. The coffin is gone.
Maybe you've got the wrong crypt В—В— after all it's twenty years when you wore last here.
The General shakes his head..
This was the place.

They stand there for a moment in perplexity.  Suddenly, t sound of a woman's voice singing comes very faintly to th very faintly and from a considerable distance. Both men t their heads in the direction of the singing which seems t come from the other side of the island. They look at each other, then with a curt gesture, the General beckons Oliv to follow him and strides off.

MED. CLOSE SHOT --Oliver and the General. The CAMERA TRUC WITH them as they pass under the cypress trees, their fac alternately in moonlight and shadow. The sound of the wom voice singing cones over the scene very faintly.

MED. SHOT - To the right, a stairway cut into the rock wi upward from the sandy floor of the beach. The CAMERA PANS SLOWLY UP the rock to the head of the stairway, a narrow shelf or landing above the sea. A square opening is cut i the cliff-face, black and impenetrable from this angle. A the CAMERA RESTS ON the tunnel opening, the minor melody the singing rises to an impassioned lament, wild and melancholy. REVERSE ANGLE. From the shelf, CAMERA SHOOTS DOWN onto th stairway. The two men are starting up the steps, the Gene in the lead. They move upward slowly, hesitantly. The sin continues, clear and alluring. MED. SHOT. Oliver and the General come up onto the shelf rock. Before then is the tunnel opening, an ominous door darkness in the moonlit stone. (See page 113 "HELLAS".) A the two men face it, the singing comes to a climax on a h almost triumphant note. There is a moment's after-silence then the earlier motif of the song begins again, subdued, softer, as if the singer were moving away. CLOSE SHOT. The General stares off, rapt, his entire bein focused on the unseen singer. CAMERA DRAWS BACK to includ Oliver, who stands a little to one side, watching the General. The General moves forward and        Oliver acco him. CAMERA TRUCKS WITH them, until they are framed in th opening of the tunnel. They stand there for a second, tha move forward again. Their figures grow dimmer as the CAME TRUCKS WITH then into the blackness of the tunnel. The singing continues, faint and slightly distorted. Over it sound the slow, hesitant footsteps of the two men. REVERSE SHOT - Beyond then, the darkness of the tunnel is broken by a light that moves wraithlike across one of the atone walls. Moonlight is pouring down from a long slit i the rock, where the wall curves up into the tunnel ceilin MED. CLOSE SHOT. Oliver and the General step into the lit pool of moonlight and look up at the aperture above them. two men turn away and continue into the darkness of the tunnel. The singing continues over all this, growing a li stronger again.

location: THE OTHER END OF THE TUNNEL

text: The two men emerge from the tunnel. To the right are limestone cliffs, before them darkness. To the left is pa of a house wall, with a door -- a dark and forbidding doo oak and iron. Now the woman's singing is loud and near. T General stares at the house, looks at the surrounding darkness and then back to the house again.
(bewilderedly) There was no house here.

Oliver and the General cross to the house. At the door, t General listens a moment, then lifts his hand and thunder the panels with his knuckles. The sound of the singing br off instantly and they stand waiting in the moonlit silen Suddenly the door opens before them and lamplight makes a frame about them. A man's voice, cheery and welcoming, co from the doorway.
Come in, come in!
They step through the doorway and the door closes behind them.

It is a lovely room of simple austere proportion, warm wi lamplight, comfortable with chairs and sofas and heated b brazier full of coals. Various antiquities, heads, bits o sculpture, torsos, limbs, bowls, vases amphoras and cylix decorate the room. At one end is a long table on which various shards, artifacts, have been arranged for labor a sorting. On this table are also books and measuring instruments. The various people in the room turn curiously upon the entrance of the soldier and the correspondent. It is Albr who is welcoming, them. He is a Swiss of middle age, a scholarly, gentle man with a humorous smile. Before the brazier, warming his behind under his coattail just as he would have done in Devonshire, is a ruddy-face Englishman, also of middle age. He is formally dressed an has a stiff, official air. This is Mr. Thomas St. Aubyn, British Consul at Adrianople. Seated some little distance from him in a stiff-backed ch is a woman in her early thirties, still possessed of a haggard beauty. There is a curious, restrained stillness about the woman and when she moves it is with a certain careful deliberation. She is working on a hand embroidery frame. After one glance at the newcomers, she pays no fur attention to them. This is Mary Wollsten, secretary to th Consul. She is dressed primly In dark clothing. - - At a small table by himself with a tankard of wine before and an empty wine bottle on the table, is a commercial traveller, Henry Jacks, a Cockney, dressed in a loud, fuz plaid suit, and seeming at this moment to be somewhat the worse for wear and liquor. The General and Oliver look around the room in astonishme Albrecht himself shows some surprise now that he sees the General in the fully lighted room.
(surprised) I took it for granted you gentlemen were refugees as are my other guests.
This is General Nikolas Pherides, Commander of the Third Army. I'm Oliver Davis. (he hesitates) To be perfectly frank with you, we didn't expect to find anyone living here.
It is my home. (extending his hand) My name is Hugo Albrecht.
Oliver shakes hands with Albrecht. The General bows.
I have not been on the island in twenty years. It is changed - changed completely. Where are the graves -- the coffins?
(turning to his guests in polite explanation) This was once a cemetery.
The people in the room exhibit varying degrees of interes
(smiling) It may seem an odd choice for a home. Yet I like it. (to Oliver and the General) But you must meet my guests.
He half turns to indicate the Consul.
This is Mr. St. Aubyn, British Consul from Adrianople.
St. Aubyn bows formally. The General returns his bow with nod, and Oliver goes forward and shakes the Consul's hand
--        and Miss St. Aubyn.
Cathy smiles wanly in greeting. Oliver, in American fashi goes from her father to Miss St. Aubyn, takes her hand.
You were singing, weren't you? A beautiful voice, Miss St. Aubyn.
(masking irritation) That was my companion. She sings little peasant songs quite nicely -- a completely untrained voice, of course.
St. Aubyn continues the introductions, indicating the som faced woman, who sits apart from the others.
My secretary, Miss Wollsten.
At this point, Jacks rises unsteadily and lurches towards others. He flashes a card from his pocket.
Jacks -- Henry Jacks. Tinware, best grade and the lowest prices -- (as if quoting a well known slogan) Jacks sells no junk.
The General looks at him, astonished at this strange commercial personality. Oliver, having shaken hands with Wollsten, nods across to Jacks amiably.
Aren't you a little out of your territory?
If the world won't come to Jacks, Jacks goes to the world.
He walks unsteadily back to his own seat.
Mr. Jacks is a philosopher. (to the General) (and Oliver) But, come, sit down with us. We are all anxious to hear of' today's battle.
(to General) A fine fight, sir, but a bit inconvenient for travel. We were under constant shelling all the way down the coast.
The enemy is in retreat. There will be no more fighting here. (to Albrecht) I came here to visit the crypts. My wife was buried here. What happened to the bodies?
They were gore before I came here.
But why?

Ida, the woman servant, a middleВ—aged Greek woman in pea costume, with a dark sombre face, comes in. She has an amphora of wine and two glasses in her hands. She pours w for Oliver and hands him the glass, then turns to the Gen and begins to pour for him as he and Albrecht talk.
There was some trouble here В—В—the villagers on the mainland В—-this island was the focal point of their anger. They came here В—В—broke open the tombs and despoiled the graves.
All the graves?
I'm afraid so. There were rumors В—В—people were aroused. Some feared restlessness among the dead you know, the old superstitions.
I donut understand.
I can explain, Master Soldier.
She has put down the amphora so that her hands are free. lifts a foreВ—finger to each side of her mouth and grimac between the upright fingers.
(understanding her immediately) Vorvolakas!
Hastily Ida crosses herself, at the same time nodding agreement
(not too unpleasantly) You are an old fool.

(grinning; pleased at this insult from her heroic countryman) You think so? You think such things do not happen? Right now В—В— upstairs there is one who is rosy and bright В—В— full of blood -- and here В—В— (she makes a sidewise inclination of her head toward Mrs. St. Aubyn) В—В—        here is one who is pale and cold as a lily.
You are still a fool.
Ida laughs and Albrecht picks up the amphora and starts t pour another glass of wine for the General.
(to Albrecht) You know the Greek legends, you drink the Greek wine, but you are not a Greek.
Albrecht is carrying the wine jug and glasses to a small table near the brazier.
I am, Greek, sir, by affection. Albrecht puts down the jug and the glasses and turns to General.
But the gods played a little trick on me. I was born in Switzerland.
(pointing to an antique statue) You collect these to sell, abroad?
Albrecht, starting to pour from the wine jug, shakes his head.

(shaking his head) No more. One day I stood in the Royal Museum at Munich and watched the fat burghers and their broodВ—mare wives staring and poking at my beautiful trophies. Now I am content just to live В—В— here in the heart of a vanished world.
(butting in without moving from his place) I wish it'd vanish, I do. I'd give every bloomin' statue in the place for one whiff of fish 'n' chips В—- for one peek at Piccadilly.
Each to his taste.
Jacks gets up, lurching and steadying himself on the tabl

I'm going back, first boat to England. I'm going back and hear the sound of Bow Bells. (gets up and starts to the stairs; complaining as he walks) I'm not well. I'm not well. Something's wrong with me В—В—something hurts.
(disdainfully) Odd way to describe plain drunkenness.

Jacks pays no attention to him, but goes on up the stairs the rest watching. The stairs are lit in such a way that upper portion is in complete darkness, shadowed by the landing above.  As Jacks disappears into this darkness, t is a sound of a heavy fall, a muttered curse. They all tu to face the staircase and Oliver and the General get to t feet. Albrecht picks up a lychnos and crosses quickly to stairs, followed by St. Aubyn. As he holds the lamp aloft the General comes to stand beside him. MED. SHOT В— past Albrecht, St. Aubyn and the General at foot of the stairs, to the upper portion of the stairs, n lit by Albrecht's lamp. Jacks lies sprawled across the to step. Bending over him is a girl in Greek native costume, gold coins of her headdress trembling at her ears, as if had been arrested in startled movement. The girl, Thea, slowly lifts her head to face the people below her. As sh does so, the General makes a sudden move forward: a move recognition and astonishment В—В— then restrains himself stand rigidly still. MED. SHOT В— Thea.
(simply) He fell.
As if words had released them, Albrecht and. St. Aubyn st up the stairs to Jacks.
(a little breathless) That's a strong wine В—В— poor fellow, I should have warned him.

As they reach Jacks, who is mumbling and trying to get to feet, Thea starts down the stairs. It is then that she se the General, who still stands rigid, staring up at her as she were an apparition. She hesitates a moment, a step or above the bottom of the stairs, held there by the General fixed gaze. Behind her, Albrecht and Ida have gotten Jack his feet. The man is muttering incoherently.
There -- you're all right, now В—В—        we have you В—В—
(disgustedly) Never mind. It'll get him to his room.

Ida and Jacks go on upstairs and Albrecht holds the lante to give them light. The General stares at Thea. CLOSE SHOT В— Oliver. He is staring off in the direction the staircase, his face revealing pleasure in seeing this beautiful Greek girl. ANOTHER ANGLE В— Thea and the General. Thea is looking ba toward Jacks. The General is studying her. Suddenly, she turns toward him to go down the stairs. For a moment she faces him full face. He looks at her in amazement greatly agitated. CLOSE SHOT - The General looking at Thea. His face is strained and he seems to have suffered from a shock. MED. FULL SHOT - The General watching Thea. Albrecht comi down the stairs looks at him.
My dear sir, you look completely exhausted.
The General attempts to pull himself together.
(coming into the scene) He is exhausted.
Why don't you stay here tonight? Get a good sleep. You can return to your command in the morning.
The General is about to shake his head in a negative answ when he suddenly thinks better of it and still looking at Thea, speaks.
Perhaps I had better stay. I am tired.
I'll get Ida to make up your bed.

He starts upstairs. Oliver and the General turn back into room. TWO SHOT        В— Cathy and Thea. They arc seated on the CAMERA is set up TO SHOOT PAST their profiles        so t and the General can be seen coming down the room from the stairway in the background.
(to Thea) The young man, Mr. Davis, seems to be some kind of an unofficial observer В—В— a correspondent of some sort В—В—
And the soldier -- He looked at me so strangely -- who is he?
Before Cathy can answer Oliver has come close to stand be them. In the background General Pherides has crossed to t brazier where Mr. St. Aubyn stands.
I don't really know where Thea comes from. The ViceВ—Consul at Adrianople brought her to me..
Her name is Thea?
Theodosia.
Her family name?
Damn me, if I know. She's become so much a member of our household I never think of her by any name but Thea -- she has a last name --
He wrinkles his forehead.
I seem to have forgotten.
The General looks at him suspiciously.
You do not know her last name -- you do not know from where she came?
(looks off at his secretary) Miss Wollsten -В— my secretary, she'd know.

MED. FULL SHOT - Miss Wollsten. She gets up, places one o the long needles she uses in her embroidery work through collar of her dress and starts toward the stairway. FULL SHOT - The General and St. Aubyn as they watch Miss Wollsten pass. She nods "good night." The General turns b to St. Aubyn.
(with a gesture toward Cathy) Your daughter is ill.
(brushing off the question) She's not too well.
(persistently) What is her illness?
Nothing, really. She's been under a great strain -- the journey -- the battle --
Was she ill before that girl came into your household?
(embarrassed at this interrogation) Why -- no not before Thea came В—В—
The General looks at him and then at Thea.
Your daughter is weak -- she feels as if the blood had been drained from her -- and all this since that girl came to work in your house.
St. Aubyn looks at him in annoyance. This volunteered diagnosis offends him. He turns toward the stairs. The General turns with him, taking hold of his arm to stop hi
This girl --
(interrupting) This girl -- Thea В—- is not a servant in my household, sir. She is my daughter's companion. Now, sir, if you'll excuse me, I'll go have a look at Mr. Jacks.
I will go with you.

Mr. St. Aubyn starts for the stairs and the General stalk after him. The two men reach the foot of the stairs MED. CLOSE SHOT - Oliver with Thea and Cathy. He smiles i friendly fashion at Thea, as he says:
I hope Mr. Jacks gets to bed in one piece.

M~ father will take care of it. (gushing to impress Oliver) Pappa is wonderful! No matter what happens, he makes me feel perfectly safe. (with flirtatious emphasis) I could never leave him. I should be utterly helpless by myself.
(gravely) You are fortunate in your father.
Thea is an orphan.
(to Thea) That was a lovely song you sang before we came. Sing it again, will you?
Thea smiles, pleased at his request. Before she can reply Cathy breaks in.
(apologetically) I adore hearing Thea sing -- but my poor head's beginning to ache. (exaggeratedly) I'm so sorry.
(courteously) Of course. Tomorrow, perhaps, before I go?

Thea nods and Oliver looks at her, seeing how very beauti how very desirable she is. He smiles and a radiant answer smile comes to her lips. Cathy, watching them, draws thei attention with a sigh. She leans back against the pillows exhaustedly and a little shudder moves her shoulders. The instantly all concern, bends over her.
You have a chill! You must have a glass of wine.

She crosses quickly to the little table and picks up the amphora. She brings it back with her, Oliver and Cathy ar talking. She has to wait, holding the cold pitcher until Cathy turns and holds out her glass. Cathy waits for Oliv to finish speaking before she passes the glass to Thea.
You can imagine the General's disappointment when he found his wife's body gone.
He turns to Thea.
Then we heard you singing --it was so strange and eerie in a place where we had thought there was only the dead.
As Oliver finishes speaking, Cathy holds out her glass to Thea, who begins to pour wine into it.
I was thinking of death when I sang.
(protesting) Thea!
Thea finishes pouring the wine and puts down the amphora. chilled jug has made her hands cold. She rubs them togeth then blows on them. Cathy and Oliver watch her, both smil Cathy shivers.
You're making me feel cold.
Thea is instantly concerned.
Perhaps my scarf --

Thea nods, smiles and willingly goes to get it. FULL SHOT - Thea. The CAMERA PANS WITH her to the foot of stairs. Here she pauses and from a small marble bench tak up a lychnos, sets it alight from another that is burning there and with this lamp in her hand begins to ascend the stairs. MED. SHOT of the stairs. Tall and lovely, with almost measured grace, Thea ascends the stairs to the second flo landing, then comes up onto the landing and pauses, looki down the corridor. She holds up her lamp. LONG SHOT - CAMERA SET UP BEHIND Thea, so that it sees wh she sees before her. In the corridor there are three poin of illumination. One from the skylight; two from windows. These three sources of light cut the blackness of the corridor into almost equal sections; oblongs of blackness alternating with rectangles of grey moonlight. Around The there is a nimbus of weak and~ wavering light, the illumination from her little lamp. The whole corridor is very still, very oppressive. Thea d in her breath almost as if taking courage, and moves towa the first patch of blackness. At its edge she hesitates a steps forward, with a little rush of movement. For a mome she is lost to view, then emerges in the first patch of moonlight. She moves slowly across this. Then again, at t very edge of the second section of darkness, she pauses. There is a little sound in the darkness; some scuffling o papers or blowing curtain. She stops stock still, begins lift her lamp. The lamp flame flickers, and then a sudden soft draft makes the flame lean far from the wick, pulsat puff out. The loss of the light leaves Thea cleft between darkness and moonlight. Again she takes a sharp intake of breath, again moves on and is lost to view, only to emerg again in the second section of light. She moves normally across this patch toward the darkness of a door set into deep embrasure. MED. CLOSE SHOT as Thea emerges from the darkness and tur right, her hand already outstretched for the doorknob. A figure obtrudes itself from the deeper blackness of the d embrasure. A hand reaches out to seize her wrist. She giv half stifled scream of fear and looks up into the face of General as it emerges into the light.
You blew out the light -- to see better in the darkness.
Thea shakes her head, perplexed, still frightened. She lo at the lamp in her hand. The General reaches out his hand point out the lamp. Their hands touch. He draws his hand quickly.
And your hands are cold В—- cold as dead hands.
Thea is too terrified to speak.
(with menacing softness) You. You know me?
Thea shakes her head, too torrified to speak.
Swear it. By your winding shroud, do you swear it?
Thea shrinks away, still unable to utter a sound. The Gen realizes that his questioning is futile. He releases her wrist, but still holds her fast with his fixed, accusing gaze.
(slowly) Maybe you have no memory for the past В—В— (in a whisper) Vrykolaka!

With the word, terror takes her. She makes a quick moveme to flee. Just as quickly he seizes her, dragging her to h He has to hold both her hands; then pulls her up against chest. He repeats the word without any special meaning. H face, across which a narrow beam of light falls obliquely grotesque and horrible. The girl struggles and her strugg free one hand. She pushes herself away from him and quick makes the sign of the cross between herself and the Gener at the same time whispering hurriedly.
Christ be with me В—В—
For a bare second, there is silence between them and then quite suddenly, he releases her other hand and begins to with laughter. She stands amazed, too wonder-struck even flee, almost gaping at him.
(through his laughter) You thought me a Vrykolaka -В—a vampire - -
He pinches his arm.
Look -- I am alive.
He begins to laugh again.
And I thought the same of you! (sobering) I am ashamed. A grown man --
The General smiles in ridicule of his own foolishness,
We of the mountain villages are strange people. There are too many old dreams in our blood, eh?
Thea smiles in agreement.
Then you can understand -- you can forgive me.
Again she smiles. He starts to move away from her. He has gone through the black patch of darkness nearest them and emerged into the moonlight on the other side. She lifts h head and calls to him.
General В—В—
He turns.
What do they call you? What is your name?
Nikolas Pherides.
He turns and continues down the corridor. CLOSEUP of Thea. A strange look comes over her face. From stare, it is evident that the name strikes some sharp cho in her mind.

It is a bright morning and between the two portals of a ruined temple can be seen the sunlit sea. (See page 98 "Hellas") In the space between the two portals, three people are grouped, Cathy, Thea and Albrecht. Cathy is seated on one the white stones, leaning back against the wall, a rug wrapped about her knees. Albrecht stands behind and a lit in back of her, while Thea stands leaning gracefully agai the opposite portal, half silhouetted against the brightn of the sea. For a moment they remain quiet, then suddenly Thea throws her arms in a gesture of ecstasy and speaks almost as if herself.
The sea! The sea!
Albrecht stares at her, arrested by the words.
What made you say that, Thea?

The woman servant, dressed in gay natio costume, waits on the table. MED. SHOT of Dr. Drossos and group at one end of the tabl Dr. Drossos refills Miss Wollsten's glass and carries the bottle to his own glass with an unsteady hand.
(thickly) When I was a young man, I prescribed moderation in all things. Especially wine.

Dr. Drossos fills his glass to the brim and then continue pouring, so that the bright liquid spills over onto the table. Miss Wollsten laughs softly and a little drunkenly Albrecht takes the bottle out of the doctor's hand, setti it upright again. The General smiles and picks up his win glass.
When I was young a man was measured by the skins of wine he could empty.

Albrecht looks toward the other end of the table and lift his glass. NED. CLOSE SHOT of Cathy, Thea and Oliver. They are sitti with their heads close together, in intimate conversation Cathy and Oliver are smiling gaily. Thea smiles, too, but rather puzzledly as if the conversation eluded her. Olive speaking in a very low tone, almost whispering. Plainly, wine has had an effect
(mockly melodramatic) And then - - the Vrykolaka will get you, if you don't watch out...
Cathy, more animated than we have ever seen her between t wine and her growing interest in Oliver, starts to laugh.
Oh, no -В— it's too delicious! You're making it up!
On my word! That's what they believe.
(smiling but distressed) Please.. You shouldn't laugh --
(teasing her) You see? Thea believes it, too!
Cathy turns to Thea. Where Oliver's teasing is good-tempe her mocking laughter has an edge of malice to it.
Tell me about them, Thea. They have great wings end long teeth --
(embellishing) Sharp, shiny teeth -- and they creep up to your bed --
Closer and closer В—- until they bite into your throat!

As she says it, Cathy's fingers dart out and touch Thea's throat. Thea gives a little muffled cry and throws hersel back from Cathy. Cathy and Oliver both burst out laughing leaning close together, sharing their childish joke.
Oh, my poor simple Thea! (to Oliver) Did you ever see anything so ludicrous?

Thea, frightened by the conversation and unhappy because Oliver and Cathy have been making fun of her, starts to g up from the table. MED. SHOT of table, including both groups, with Oliver, C and Thea in the background. As Thea stands up, Dr. Drosso leans forward, peering down the table towards her.
Thea! Come here!
The others turn to look at the girl as she obeys the summ
Look at her. Warm, beautiful - alive. Drink with me, Thea -В— Drink to my old enemy, who wins at last --

As Thea comes to stand beside him, Dr. Drossos picks up Albrecht's wine glass and hands it to her. Thea obedientl drinks. In silence they watch her drain the glass, her he going back slowly. It is a beautiful, a pagan gesture.
(almost to himself) There is only one place where the women bewitch one with their beauty.

CLOSE SHOT of Thea as she starts singing. It's a primitiv sensuous song and Thea's whole body seems to respond.. MED. CLOSE SHOT of Oliver and Cathy, watching Thea. It is obvious that Oliver is bewitched; his eyes follow every m the girl makes. Cathy steals a glance at him. ANOTHER ANGLE as Thea sings; she moves toward Oliver in a series of slow steps. As she comes closer to him, she sta to smile, a slow dreamlike smile that seems to well up fr some deep inner joy. Oliver leans forward, drawn by the g until as she comes within reach he puts out his hand to t her arm. Her smile quivers into a little laugh, at once childish and enticing. She eludes him. At this moment, he song ends. While the        others applaud, she crosses t door. There, she stops abruptly. CLOSEUP of Thea, looking across the room at Oliver. Her f flushed and alive, is a frank invitation, almost innocent its candid admission of desire. Then she slowly turns her head away. CLOSE SHOT of Oliver as Thea slips out the door in the b. He gets to his feet. Cathy puts out her hand to hold him but he doesn't even see it. As Oliver walks past the tabl unsteadily, the General gets to his feet and blocks his w Oliver pushes him aside impatiently.
Everything's dead in here, dead and empty. (gesturing toward the door) Out there; the night is alive.
He continues across and goes out through the door.
(starting for the door; harshly) Someone should go with him. He's has had too much to drink.
Suddenly Miss Wollsten laughs. Cathy whirls around to sta at her angrily. Miss Wollsten returns the stare.
I think Thea is steady enough for both. She has not had too much to drink.
The General looks at her with hatred and crosses back to chair and sits down. Miss Wollsten, with a smile, turns a goes upstairs.
(almost incoherently) Don't go. You are leaving me, you are all leaving me --
Albrecht, instantly concerned, gets up and bonds over the dying man.
I'm here. The General is here. You are not alone.
(with a last spurt of strength) I must meet him with laughter - with songs and laughter -- to show him I am not afraid --

With the last words, Dr. Drossos catches up his wine glas but, before he can lift it to his lips he begins to slump his chair. The echo of his final challenge dies. The Gene steps quickly to his side.
He is dying.
Dr. Drossos doubles up in his chair and falls limply forw across the table. His hand relaxes and the wine glass fal the wine spilling out with the doctor's life.
(slowly) When she stood beside him, I knew. I could feel death in the room.

MED. SHOT В— Cathy, alone, paces the little terrace outsi the house. It is evident that she is disturbed and agitat by something. After a moment, the sound of Thea's voice, singing, comes into the still morning air. Cathy stops, listening. CLOSER SHOT of Cathy, her face hardening with angry jealo as she listens to Thea's clear, sweet song. Oliver comes the ruins. Cathy turns as Oliver comes toward her, smilin he looks off in the direction of the singing.
(emotionally) Oliver --
Oliver's smile fades into concern as he comes up to take Cathy's hand in quick sympathy.
What is it, Cathy? What's the matter?

MED. CLOSE SHOT of Cathy and Oliver. The singing continue over this entire scene, sometimes louder, sometimes faint as if Thea were strolling about the island. Cathy's expression is distraught and she clings to Oliver hand.
My father -- I'm alone, Oliver, completely alone!
(tenderly) Poor Cathy --
(with rising hysteria) Last night Dr. Drossos -- today you or I -- oh, no, Oliver, it can't be you, I couldn't stand it.
Cathy, clutching Oliver's hand tightly, leans toward him yearningly. Oliver, beginning to find her emotionalism awkward and a little distasteful, is deliberately matter- fact now.
There's no reason to decide any of us are going to die.
If only we could get away - - you and I. The others are strangers, they mean nothing to me
Struck by this callousness, Oliver's face loses the last trace of sympathy for Cathy.
(feverishly) We have to get away, we have to live. I have no one in the world -- you must stay with me, care for meВ—

Making an effort to control his instinctive aversion to h closeness, Oliver takes hold of her arms and pulls them a at the same time stepping back from her. He smiles at her trying to return their relationship to a normal footing.
We'll talk later, when you're yourself again.

Cathy still stands motionless and Oliver walks away in th direction of Thea's singing, which now comes over the sce clearly. CAMERA REMAINS on Cathy, as she watches him go. face contorts and she starts weeping with rage and frustration. Abruptly, she turns and starts off.

head_text.subj: EXT THE LANDING OUTSIDE THE TUNNEL

text: The General stands here, leaning on his sabre, looking to the mainland from which comes the sound of cannonading. Behind him is a camp chair.
In the distance small puffs of smoke can be seen and the sound of canon fire comes from afar.

The General looks up at a little flag on a pole which has been erected nearby. It blows south, rippling and undulat in the brisk north wind. He turns to look back at the oth shore. Cathy comes out of the tunnel. The General turns t her.
(looking at the flag) The wind has not changed.
He shakes his head. Cathy sinks down in the camp chair. face still drawn from her emotional upset looks frighteni exhausted.
(compassionately) Poor child. These must be horrible days for you.
I'm so ill, I'm so exhausted -- I almost don't care.
The General looks at her with heightened attention.
You look so pale this morning, as if all your blood were drained away.
Cathy looks at him, her ego gratefully absorbing this attention and sympathy. The General takes a few steps bac and forth, then stops before her.
Has that girl -- has Thea ever told you where she comes from?
(not liking the change of subject) Some village in the mountains -- Alethera, I think.
The General stands very still.
Has she spoken to you of her father and her mother?
(indifferently) She has never mentioned her family.
How old is she?
The General waits tensely for the answer, which means so to him. Cathy, now definitely bored by the trend of the conversation, replies cattily:
(indifferently) I don't know --- fairly young.
The General stands silent. Cathy gets up languidly and st for the tunnel.
The sun is so strong here.
The General watches her depart, then walks to the edge of landing and starts down towards the beach.

LONG SHOT - HIGH CAMERA SETUP. The sunlight drifts in lon beams between the trees. At the end of one of these rays light, Thea is seated on a block of marble. In her lap ar some myrtle leaves and she is happily occupied in weaving them into a crown. MED. CLOSE SHOT - Thea. Suddenly a tall shadow falls over her. She looks up. ANOTHER ANGLE. The General stands before Thea. She looks without a smile of greeting.
You have deceived me long enough. Now I have found out. You are from Alethera -- from where I took you and from where you came to die - - to die without dying - -
Thea rises and faces him.
Why are you making up these things - - why are you wishing evil on me? (as if answering her own question) You know who I am, don't you?
(slowly) I wish I didn't know.        I wish I had never found you again.
I knew you hated me and my people -- but I didn't know your hatred was so bitter --
The General's expression softens. He shakes his head sadl
It isn't hatred. I couldn't hate you.
Thea looks at him wonderingly, struck by the change in hi tone.
(somberly) I failed you twenty years ago. Now, I've come to do what must be done.
Thea's face lights up. She says, almost hopefully:
To take me with you?
The General draws back from her in horror, believing as h does that she is a Vrykolaka. With his left hand he begin reach inside his tunic.
(in a hoarse whisper) No - - no -- to do what I should have done.
At this moment, a call comes from above.
Thea --
The General looks off towards the voice.
Thea --
(calling) I'm here..
The General lets go her arm.
(in a low voice) I watched you -- you've bewitched him. But he is my friend. You'll not do to him what you have done to the young English girl.
Thea turns and runs. The General stands looking after her

location: THE LOWER END OF THE PATH LEADING FROM THE HOUSE

text: Oliver comes leisurely down the path to the three or four steps which brings it to the floor of the grove. He stops suddenly as Thea runs in very agitated. She runs up to hi and he takes her in his arms.
Thea, what's wrong?
The General threatened me.

(grinning) Oh, that Vrykolaka business. You mustn't be too angry with him, Thea. He's an old man and now with all this trouble В—В— the disappointment in not being able to lead his own army to victory -- cooped up here waiting for death - naturally his mind goes back to the things he believed when he was an ignorant lad in some mountain village.
He keeps asking for the name of my father and mother.
Well, tell, him.
I can't.
Why in the world can't you?
He hates all my race.
I knew that feuds still went on, but I didn't think people like you and the General would be involved.
It is more than a feud between two families. He stole my mother away from her people.
Oliver looks at her, holding her out at arm's length.
Thea, what is this? What are you trying to tell me? "He stole your mother" В—-
(nodding) It is for that he hates me.
Oliver shakes his head.
(earnestly) I don't think so, Thea. He has spoken of your mother. I don't believe he knows you are his daughter.
Then why does he persecute me? My family told me what kind of man he is, how he stole my mother and then abandoned her --
Oliver takes her hand.
(gently) They didn't tell you the whole truth. Why do you think your mother went back to him after you were born?
Thea looks at him, uncertain, unconvinced.
Because she loved him. (pauses) I know him, Thea. Believe me, he is not a cruel man.
(slowly) For a moment, when he looked at me so sadly, I felt that I had wronged him. But then --
She shudders, remembering her last sight of the General.'
Let me tell him. When he knows you are his child, he'll forget these insane notions -В—
(alarmed) No -- you musn't. He thinks I've bewitched you. He won't believe it В—- he'll hate me even more! My only chance is to stay away from him.
Oliver puts his arm around her in a protective gesture.
Perhaps you are right. He's not himself now. We'll wait В—В— and in the meantime, don't be afraid I'll take care of you..
Thea gives him a faint, grateful smile and rests her head against his shoulder trustingly.

head_text.subj: THE NARROW LEDGE IN FRONT OF THE CRYPTS

text: The General turns onto the ledge and begins walking. From crypt comes the sound of someone moving about. He stops.

A crude wooden coffin stands on two trestles in the cente the crypt. Beside it stands Miss Wollsten. Suddenly the b of the General blocking the doorway shuts off the light falling into the crypt. Miss Wollsten looks up startled. TWO SHOT - The General and Miss Wollsten.
Woman, what are you doing here?

(rising to her feet and attempting to look more normal and a little strange and guilty) I wanted to be sure of something, General -- something that has always preyed on my mind. I have a horror of being buried alive and awakening to find myself shut in В—- entombed В—В— imprisoned..
(pointing to the coffin) He sleeps quietly. He died with a wine glass in his hand -- he died laughing -- a brave man, Drossos, like his father before him.
Because he was a brave man - because I liked him -- I came here to be sure.
He's dead enough. God rest his soul.
He starts to turn away.
General -В—
He turns back to her.
I'm a woman -- a lonely woman. I have few friends.
(impatiently) Yes?
I have not had a happy life --but that one thing - - that terror which brings me awake out of deep sleep В—- I want to avoid it.
I don't understand you.
I don't want to be buried alive. If I die I want to be sure В—- quite sure.
If you should fall sick we'll be careful. You need not worry.
No, I want more than that. I beg you General, make sure --drive a knife through my heart -- anything.
(looking at her in sudden horror) You ask that of me? You're afraid to live in your coffin. You know what that means?
(nods) That's superstition. That's something out of old tales -- about the dead who live В—- I'm talking of something else --cataleptic attacks -- apparent death that is not real.

Never fear -- when you are dead you will remain dead. I will see to it that you do not walk about again. I promise you that. There is another one here who can not die. I will watch you both. Never fear.
He turns and walks away from her. Miss Wollsten looks aft him with a puzzled expression. She makes a half move as i stop him for explanation then thinks better of it and let him go.

Albrecht sits at the long table where he sorts his artifa Oliver sits on the table facing him. THE CAMERA PANS FROM the scientist and Oliver to the woma servant who is setting the table and the man servant who pouring charcoal into the brazier. As the charcoal covers live coals that corner of the room grows dim and the CAME PANS TO the foot of the stairs.

Thea stands in front of the mirror brushing her long hair Suddenly, there is a small movement in the glass alongsid her reflection. She stops brushing, poised in midair, pee into the glass, then whirls to look at the window.

A face hardly discernible and unrecognizable is disappear from the glass. CLOSE SHOT - Thea. She looks in puzzlement at the window, then with a little shrug, she lays down her brush and beg to pile up her hair and put on her head-dress. She finish bends swiftly to put out the oil light and goes out the d The room is plunged into darkness, except for the lighted doorway of Miss Wollsten's room.

DOLLY SHOT The CAMERA MOVES BEFORE Thea as she comes down dark hallway. The top button of her dress needs fastening she is concentrating on it as she walks. Behind her a vag form seems to be emerging from the darkness. At the stair landing she pauses.

FULL CLOSE SHOT - Thea - as she pauses to finish adjustin the button. Behind her, the half-seen dimness of the figu that has followed her down the hall emerges fully in the person of the General. Just as he comes into clear perception, Thea finishes fastening the button of her dro and starts down the stairs, quite oblivious of his threatening proximity. He stops at the top of the stairs.

The CAMERA IS SET UP IN a corner with a wide angle lens taking in both the door to the hall and the door to Miss Wollsten's room. The room is in darkness, but Miss Wollst room glows with a dim light. Miss Wollsten comes into the doorway of her room. In her hand is one of the little lychnoses. She hears a knock at the hall doorway. She hesitates a second, then puts out the lamp, plunging the in darkness. At this instant, the door from the hail open admitting light as well as the General. The General strik match and sets flame to the oil lamp which Thea left in t room. When the room is illuminated, Miss Wollsten has disappeared and only the black emptiness of her doorway c be seen. The General holds up the lamp and looks around. walks into the room and CAMERA PANS WITH him as he crosse the window.
General -В—
The General turns back towards the hall door, startled. ANOTHER ANGLE - including both the General and Cathy, who stand in the open doorway to the hall.
What are you doing?
I was looking for you.
The General walks over to her.
I have been troubled about you. I want you to know that my room is just downstairs -- (nodding toward hail) You have only to cry out if you are ill В—В— or frightened.
(pleased) How kind you are. It is so comforting to know that someone cares.
As she speaks, Cathy goes into the room and sits on the e of her bed.
(kindly) You no longer have your father В—- (smiles almost affectionately) And I have no children.
The General turns to leave the room, then looks back towa the other bed.
Miss Wollsten shares the room with you?
No, that's Thea's bed. Miss Wollsten's bed is in there.
Cathy gestures toward the darkened doorway of Miss Wollst room. The General looks for a second longer at Thea's bed then nods as he starts out.
(smiling) I'll see you at dinner.
As the General closes the door behind him, Cathy gets up crosses to the dressingВ—table. From behind her, out of the darkness of her own room, com Miss Wollsten.
I've always known what an evil mind lay behind that pretty weak face of yours В—В— but this, Cathy -- even I would never have believed it is of you.
(genuinely bewildered) Would you care to explain what you're talking about?
You've been playing on the superstitions of that poor old man В— В— working at him В— В— turning him against Thea.
(angrily) Really, this is idiotic!
You'd do anything to get Oliver away from Thea. But I'm going to stop you. I'm going to tell Mr. Davis exactly what you are.
Cathy's bewilderment has this time given way to rage, as ancient antagonism between the two women flares up again.
And what makes you think he'll believe you, when I tell him what you are - - what part you played in my father's life --
Miss Wollsten shrinks back from her, appalled at the interpretation Cathy's tone gives to her love for St. Aub
When I tell him that you're unfit to live a normal life with normal people В—- a cataleptic!
(stricken) You wouldn't tell that В—В—
Wouldn't I?
Now, Miss Wollsten's calm leaves her. She almost shrieks the girl.

Then tell them! You're despicable, a monster of vanity with heart for no one but yourself. Tell them everything -- but I will tell them too В—- and you'll lose, Cathy -- you understand -- you'll lose!

She turns from Cathy, picks up the lamp and goes back to own room. Cathy looks after her, her expression of rage fading to an irritated frown. Then, with a shrug, she pic up the lychnos and walks out of the room to the hall.

The bed is turned down and a white cotton nightgown hangs over the footboard. Miss Wollsten picks up a shawl and adjusts it with a frenzied movement about her shoulders. starts to pick up the lamp, then suddenly stops; her face contorts, her lips writhe in strangulated agony and very slowly her knees buckle. She goes to her knees, to all fo and then slides from this position to the floor.

Oliver, Thea, the General and Albrecht an already seated the table  Albrecht has a soup tureen before his and is ladling out bowls of soup which the woman servant takes t the various places. Cathy, coming across the room from th staircase, goes to her place.
It has been brisk and warm today. Take comfort  We always have these perfect days before the sirocco blows.
Albrecht starts to ladle out another portion, looks towar the one empty seat and asks:
Where is Miss Wollsten?
She's in her room.
I'll get her        --
Thea gets up and moves quickly across to the stairway.
If Mr. Albrecht is right, we'll all be free in a few days. (to Cathy) I suppose you'll be going on to Athens?
(the usual) I don't know now without my father.
You are right. You shouldn't be traveling alone. (to Oliver) Why don't you make the trip with her?
Cathy turns to Oliver, waiting hopefully for his answer.
(politely disinterested) I'd like to, very much -- but it depends on what dispatches are waiting for me on the mainland.
(to Oliver) In case you do so, would you --
Albrecht's words are cut by terrible shriek from the uppe floor. For a split second, they are sit motionless and th they jump up and rush, to the staircase.
MED. SHOT on head of stairway as the group come up the stairs. The men, in the lead, cross towards the girls' ro and Cathy hurries after them.

MED. CLOSE SHOT of Thea bending over the body of Miss Wollsten. Over the scene come the sound of a door opening, quick footsteps and ad lib voices. As Thea raises her head, the CAMERA DRAWS BACK to show the General in the doorway of t room, with Oliver, Albrecht and Cathy behind him. As the General stares into the room, Thea's hand goes up to her necklace. She rises quickly as the General comes forward steps aside. The General drops to one knee beside Miss Wollsten's body. Oliver goes over to Thea and Albrecht comes to stand besi the General.
She is dead.
Cathy, still standing in the doorway, gives a little gasp draws back into her own room. CLOSE SHOT. The General opens the high neck of Miss Wollsten's dress and examines the throat and upper bosom.
There are no marks.
He looks off toward Thea. MED. SHOT. As Thea shrinks away from the General's look, Oliver puts a protective arm around her and leads her int the other room.
Help me put her on the bed.
The two men lift Miss Wollsten's body from the floor and carry it to the bed.
I want to make those tests that Dr. Drossos made. (looking down at the corpse) I promised her.
He looks around the room, then goes to the dresser and pi up a hand-mirror.

FULL SHOT - SHOOTING THROUGH the open doorway into Miss Wollsten's room. In immediate foreground Cathy and Thea s on the bed, their backs to the CAMERA. Thea has her arm around Cathy. Leaning on one side of the doorway, so as n to obstruct the view, is Oliver. The General and Albrecht can be seen bending over Miss Wollsten's bed, but we cannot see what they are doing.
Her heart is stopped -- there is no breath.
Nothing. (after a pause) There is a way to make sure -В—
Oliver moves into Miss Wollsten's room, at the same time saying sharply:
No. We can do without that.
MED. SHOT - the three men.
Another sad task. We'll bury her tomorrow. (gesturing to door) I think we'd better lock the door for tonight. It will make them less uncomfortable.
(positively) No. (looking toward the door) She shall not be left here.
Maybe you're right. Help me get something to carry her downstairs.

The figures of the three men go past the CAMERA. Their footsteps can be heard as they leave the room; the sound the door closing as they shut it behind them. The CAMERA which has remained focused on Miss Wollsten's begins to slowly MOVE IN to an extreme CLOSEUP. Here it h a moment and as it HOLDS there is a sudden twitch of musc in the woman's cheek. As the sound of the men's feet scuffling as they bring in heavy burden is heard, the CAMERA begins to PULL BACK in order to reveal the General, Albrecht and Oliver carrying a heavy packing box of the sort that the archaeologist us to ship statues and pieces of heavy stone carving. They put the box on the floor, line it with a blanket and then lift Miss Wollsten and place her in the box. While t General and Oliver get the lid from the hall, Albrecht notices the white cotton nightgown on the foot of the bed picks it up. They put the lid on the box and start to lif it.

LONG SHOT. Thea is seated and she watches Oliver, Albrech the General and the man servant as they carry the heavy b down the path from the house. Behind the men and their bu walk Cathy, Thea and the woman servant.

head_text.subj: THE LEDGE IN FRONT OF THE CRYPTS

text: The little procession comes up onto the ledge and starts walking along it to the nearest crypt, the one next to th occupied by the remains of Dr. Drossos.
The men come in with the box and set it up on two stone supports. They group themselves around it and stand a mom with bowed heads.
Rest in peace.

They all file quietly out. THE CAMERA does not move from position in which it has been set. It remains focused on coffin for a long moment, then, slowly, it begins to DOLL IN. When it has come very close to the coffin the sound o groaning can be heard from within the box, then a muffled cry, movement and the sound of fingernails scraping again the boards.

The General sits in his camp chair looking across at the mainland. Above his head the flag is streaming to the nor and a south wind, blowing, ruffles the General's hair and clothing. The General pays no attention to the flag. Oliv half running, comes out of the tunnel.
(excitedly) General! The wind --- look the wind has changed to the South.
The General glances up at the flag indifferently and then turns again to watch the mainland.
It's the sirocco -- we'll be able to get away from here -- you can take command of your army
The General shakes his head.
I have had command for the last time В—-
Come В—- you'll feel yourself again as soon as we get off this dismal island.
(starting to rise) I shall not leave the island В—В—

As he gets to his feet, he staggers. Oliver catches him a looks at him in horrified alarm. Slowly the General nods, answering the unspoken question. He has the plague. Olive takes his arm, passes it over his own shoulder and begins help him toward the tunnel.
The coffin is still sealed. But from within comes a muffl crying, the sound of fists beating on the boards, the slithering scrape of nails.

CLOSE SHOT - Miss Wollsten's face and shoulders. She has managed to free her arms from the heavy blanket. With her arms lifted above her head she is frantically pushing aga the coffin lid. As she struggles she screams and her scre echo and reverberate in the narrow confines of the coffin Exhausted by her futile efforts, Miss Wollsten stops struggling, lies still, breathing deeply, her heavy breat echoing. Then she tries to turn in the coffin. It is too narrow. A she beats on the lid. Then she tries to dig her way out w her nails. The scrape of her nails on the dull and echoin wood is the only sound. Finally, even this is too much fo her fading strength. She lies quiet, softly moaning.

Oliver and the General come up the stairs. With Oliver supporting the sick man, they start down the corridor jus Cathy comes out from her room. She watches the two men go down the corridor. She follows them. When they turn into General's room, she stands waiting in the corridor. A mom later, Oliver comes out.
(as he passes Cathy) I'm going to get Albrecht. Watch the General for me.
Cathy nods and goes on into the General's room.
Fully clothed, the General lies on his bed. Cathy comes i and stands beside him. The General looks up at her.
The wind has changed. There's no more danger for the army. You can go.
Cathy looks toward the window.
(looking toward the window) It's getting dark. I can't leave now.
(weakly) In the morning -- go. I'll not die until then В—- I'll not die В—В— I'll watch -В— they shall not hurt you.
(comfortingly) ShhВ—В—В— it's all right -В— I'll be all right.
They shall not hurt you
MED. LONG SHOT~В— the mouth of the crypt is solid black i night. From it comes a low mutter of sound.
The coffin is silhouetted against the lighter darkness of night outside the crypt. Here the muttering, moaning and whining of the entombed woman sounds louder.

Miss Wollsten is almost exhausted by her struggles. Her single garment is torn from her exertions; her face is scratched and bleeding. She lifts her hands again to tear the wooden ceiling of her prison. INSERT        MISS WOLLSTEN'S HANDS. The nails are ragged broken; blood streams from under them. CLOSE SHOT В— Miss Wollsten. She ceases to struggle; lies quietly, her eyes open. There is an expression of awarene in her face, almost as if she were listening to something Very faintly, but growing in volume, reverberated by the narrow confines can be heard a rhythmic tapping. The soun gets louder and louder. CLOSE SHOT of the crypt wall. Water is dripping down onto coffin. It drops with a certain, finite measure like the "vrykolaka", quickly and rhythmically. Several times Miss Wollsten's lips move as if repeating t words. Then another word begins to come in from underneat the phrases of the General. At first it is so low in volu then it is barely perceptible,then it grows in volume.
Vrykolaka -- Vrykolaka --
SHOT of the crypt wall. The water continues to drip onto coffin in the same rhythm as the word~

CLOSE SHOT В— Miss Wollsten's face. She is listening to t drumming of the water on the coffin. The word "Vrykolaka" repeated over and over again to the same rhythm grows lou and more insistent. She breathes rapidly. She turns her h from side to side, then finally her whole body tenses, he mouth opens and she screams.
(screaming) Vrykolaka!
With the word a convulsive movement, a frenzy of strength takes possession of her. She arches her back -and forces whole body against the lid of the coffin. It begins to splinter.

Albrecht is seated at his work bench. He has a small squa of emery paper in his hand and is meticulously attempting remove the dirt and corrosion of the ages from Poseidon's bronze trident. Oliver is watching him.
It doesn't look much like the fish spears I knew back in Marblehead..
(holding it up between him and the light) Our friend, Poseidon, didn't use it for fishing. He raked the sea with it and stirred up the big waves.
(getting up) I'll go up and take a look at the General В—- perhaps sit with him.
He won't even know you're there. He is delirious.
All the more reason to watch him. He's had some wild notions lately.
Don't bother. Go to bed and get some sleep. I'll be working late. (pointing upstairs) I can hear any movement down here.
(hesitating) Well В—В—
Go ahead. I'll wake you up when I go to bed. Then you can watch him.
Thank you, I'll do that. Good night.
Oliver walks to the stairs.

Miss Wollsten is emerging from the shattered coffin. Ther a wild and maniacal gleam in her eyes. The remnants of th white blanket still cling about her shoulders. Her white nightgown is in voluminous tatters about her bony body. S starts out from the crypt.

An oil lamp is burning on the dresser and a lighted lychn stands on a little table beside Cathy's bed. Cathy is in propped up against the pillows. Her face is drawn, her ey unhappy and almost haunted. Thea sits on the foot of Cath bed, watching her anxiously.
You should sleep, Cathy. Lie down and close your eyes. Try to forget everything.
(shaking her head) When I close my eyes, I see Miss Wollsten. I can't think of anything else.
(gently) She is dead В— at peace.
With a movement so sudden that it startles Thea, Cathy si upright.
(feverishly) Suppose, she isn't dead. Suppose it was a cataleptic attack?
It was, the plague
(interrupting) We quarreled. She never dared get angry or frightened -- but I said things to her -- it was an attack, I know it was.
Half convinced by Cathy's certainty, Thea gets up from th bed.
Then let us go to her, Cathy. We'll make sure В— and your mind will be at rest.
Cathy shrinks back against the pillows, her eyes        w terror.
(whispering) Oh, no В—- I couldn't Thea. I couldn't go into the crypt.  I'm afraid, you know I'm afraid.

For a moment, Thea stands looking at Cathy in silence. Th with an air of decision she crosses to the dresser. She p up a shawl, then puts out the oil lamp. The room fills wi shadows and only the dim glow of the lychnos illuminates scene.
(half fearfully half hopefully) What are you going to do?
Thea goes to the door and there turns back to face Cathy.
I'll be back soon. Don't worry anymore, Cathy.
Thea goes out, quietly closing the door behind her. Cathy stares after her.
A candle burns beside the bed. In the bed the Genera~ lie restlessly tossing, muttering in delirium.

The lychnos is burning dimly on a little table beside Cat bed. She lies awake, her eyes wide open, watching the sha across the ceiling. She hears Oliver's footsteps, listens identifies them, then resumes looking at the shadows.

location: THE CONVERGENCE OF THE PATHS LEADING TO THE GROVE AN

text: Thea descends the steps to the two paths and starts to ta the right-hand turn. She stops as she sees something ahea her and peers out into the darkness. There is a low moani sound. It stops. She takes two steps forward. The moaning sounds again. Thea is frightened. She stops a moment and decides to take the left-hand path to the cypress grove a the beach. She has hardly disappeared from view into the darkness of the left-hand path, when Miss Wollsten comes along the path from the crypts. She wanders in a dazed condition and there is madness in her eyes. She seems puz as to which way she should go.

Thea walks through the cypress grove under the dark trees She is nervous and stops several times. Even the sudden t of a nightingale causes her to catch her breath in surpri and stand stock still until she has identified the sound, smile at her own nervousness and pass on. All the little night sounds of the wood are exaggerated and nerve shatte to her oversensitive ears. Finally, she reaches the littl beach at the end of the cliffs and stands here safe; the space around her a guarantee against surprise.
Albrecht is nodding over his work bench. He almost falls asleep, but catches himself and takes a draught of beer f the glass beside him. He then goes on polishing the tride

location: THE STEPS LEADING TO THE LANDING

text: Thea, listening and alert, starts to climb the steps. A sudden break of surf on the shingle of the beach makes he tense. She goes on up the steps to the landing.

Thea comes up. The dark tunnel faces her. In the center through the broken roofing a shaft of moonlight cuts in. stands hesitantly before the opening, then almost as if taking her courage into her hands, she begins to walk slo shuffling one foot after the other.

Thea comes through the darkness. MED. FULL SHOT - the patch of moonlight in the tunnel. Th comes into the patch of moonlight and breathes a little m easily. She starts to take a firmer step. Ahead of her in darkness is a tiny unidentified noise. She freezes. CLOSE SHOT - Thea. She listens. Again there is the tiny unidentifiable noise; someone moving.
(softly) Who is there?

She waits for an answer. The echo of her voice is flung b at her, "Who is there В—В— Who is there" and dies away on word 'Who В—В— Who." MED. FULL SHOT - Thea in the tunnel. Ahead of her in the darkness is the movement of something white.
Is that you, Oliver?
The echoes ring around her with her own words. They die a CLOSE SHOT В— Thea. She peers into the darkness.

text: A dimly seen figure has advanced a few steps. Thea can se is a woman. MED. CLOSE SHOT - THEA.
Cathy?
FULL SHOT - Thea and the dim figure ahead of her. From th darkness comes a, ringing peal of maniacal laughter and a shouted name.
Cathy!
Thea turns and runs back toward the landing. Miss Wollste dimly seen figure disappears in the other direction.
Miss Wollsten comes running madly out of the mouth of the tunnel. She stops, peers around suspiciously, then goes t the door of the house and opens it softly.

The fire is low in the brazier. At his work bench Albrech has tipped his chair back against the wall and is sleepin Before him on the bench lies the bronze trident, its shar burnished points catching the fire light. Miss Wollsten creeps in, closes the door softly behind her and on tipto with the cunning of madness, crosses the room to Albrecht She looks at him. He continues to sleep. Stealthily she reaches between his limp hands and takes up the trident. With the trident in her hand she begins to cross the main room toward the stairs.
He is fitfully tossing.

Thea still very frightened, crouches against the stone wh supports Cerberus. She listens and there is no sound and finally taking courage, she begins to walk through the gr of cypress trees to the house.
Cathy lies still, wide awake, her eyes on the shadows on ceiling. Suddenly the door opens-- quietly and closes aga Cathy half turns her head.
Thea?

There is a rush in the darkness a stifled exclamation of fear, a quick blow with the trident and Cathy falls back her pillow dead, blood streaming from two puncture marks her throat. Miss Wollsten straightens, gazes about her fo moment, then disappears into the shadows of the room.
Thea comes in, closes the door softly behind her, smiles she sees Albrecht asleep, crosses to him and shakes him awake.
Oh -В— sleeping -- Oliver wouldn't like that. (he listens) Well, everything seems to be all right.
Goodnight.
She starts across the room and up the stairs. Albrecht, realizing his hands are empty, begins looking for the trident.

It is so still that Miss Wollsten's movements around the in the darkness can be heard. Thea opens the door and com in. She looks over at Cathy's bed. Cathy seems to be asle Without bothering to turn up the oil light, Thea turns ba the covers of her bed and begins to undress. Several time she pauses to listen as if she had hoard a slight sound, continues to take off another piece of clothing until she down to her shift. As she begins to pull down the shoulde straps of her shift a little louder noise in the darkness causes her to stop. There is no repetition of the sound. Again she starts to slip down her shoulder straps.
Albrecht is still looking for his trident. He finally giv up and takes a drink of beer.

The General is tossing wildly. He is awake and his eyes a glazed with fever. He gets up. He is dressed in his unifo trousers and a shirt. He wears neither boots nor tunic. H begins to stagger toward the door.

The General comes out of his room, supporting himself with one hand against the wall.  He moves blindly into th corridor. Several times he passes his hand before his eye if trying to clear his vision, but the blindness of the plague is upon him.
CLOSER SHOT - He comes up the stairs. He finds the door t the girls' room by touch and opens it. He has to support himself on the door jamb to prevent collapse. He shuffles

The General blindly gropes his way in. CLOSE SHOT В— Thea. She looks over in horror from the bed where she is now lying. MED. FULL SHOT - The General as he gropes his way across Cathy's bed. He kneels down beside it. CLOSE SHOT В— The General and Cathy. He gropes over her f with his hand. One hand touches the wound at her throat. touches the blood stained hand against the fingers of the other hand to test the wetness, then gropes again for the wound. CLOSE SHOT В— The General and Cathy. He touches the two puncture marks.
(muttering) Vrykolaka.

His hand goes down to feel Cathy's heart beat. There is n The General straightens up and from his belt takes the sm sharp stick of hazel-wood. He turns and begins blindly staggering toward the other bed with outstretched hands. unseeing footsteps take him out of the periphery of the l into the darkness. CLOSE SHOT - Thea. She lies still, holding her breath, tr desperately not to move, not to make a sound, not to attr the General's attention and, give direction to his murder footsteps. She looks up at the shadows on the ceiling. Th lychnos casts weird moving shadows. CLOSE SHOT -- The General, as he gropes his way.  CLOSE SHOT - Thea, straining to see into the shadows beyo her bed. Suddenly, her face becomes completely terrorized Out of the darkness beyond the bed materialises the gener hand holding the hazel-wood stick, as it comes into the periphery of the light from to lychnos. CLOSEUP - Thea's face. She can no longer control herself. screams. MED. FULL SHOT - The General comes out of the darkness, throws himself blindly, toward Thea. ANOTHER ANGLE - silently, swiftly, Miss Wollsten comes ou the darkness, the trident gleaming in her hand. She strik down. The General's hands fall limp and harmless. The haz stick falls to the floor as the General collapses over th bed.

Oliver, rubbing the sleep from his eyes, startled by Thea scream, comes out into the corridor. Suddenly he becomes completely alert as from the girls' r Miss Wollsten emerges. Oliver looks at her with shocked horror and then rushes towards the girls' room.
Miss Wollsten comes rushing down the stairs. Albrecht loo at her in amazement. His glass of beer falls to the floor She dashes through the door into the darkness.
Albrecht comes out and peers off into the moonlight. Evidently he sees the direction of Miss Wollsten's flight Picking up a lantern, he runs after her.

MED. CLOSE SHOT - The General lies on Thea's bed. Thea, n in her robe, and Oliver bent over him. The General opens eyes. He seems darned, but his lace is calm in contrast t his former appearance  He turns his head slightly in Thea direction.
(in a whisper) Theodosia --
(with great sympathy) Not Theodosia. Theodosia's daughter -- your daughter.
The General looks from one to the other uncomprehendingly
Daughter -- my daughter --
She was born before your wife returned here to die. You never knew.

An expression of full realization comes into the General' face. He attempts to smile at Thea and makes an effort to move his hand toward her. Thea understands the gesture an puts her hand over his warmly. 'The touch of her hand ind a state of euphoria in the General. He looks at Thea gratefully, peacefully.

Fog is rising from the sea so that although the temple is still clear, the cliff ends abruptly in a curtain of grey watery vapor. Miss Wollsten, the trident held before her, comes running into the temple. She pauses, looks forward the grey wall before her. Behind her she can hear Albrech footsteps. She throws down the trident, it rings on the marble pavement of the temple. Then, almost with composur she walks slowly forward and suddenly disappears into the grey fog. From the fog comes a long, descending scream. A moment later, Albrecht appears with the lantern and stand looking off. Glancing down, Albrecht sees the trident gleaming in the light. He picks it up, examines it --
(softly to himself) With Poseidon's trident she paid her way to Hades. He let her pass through the portals into his dark realm.
The wind blows free from the South.

It is early morning and the cliffs cast long shadows over rippling catspaws on the water. A small boat is drawn up the beach. Albrecht's man servant stands in the stern, leaning on a sculling oar that he presses against the bot to hold the boat steady. Thea, with her bundle of possess beside her, sits on the thwart. Oliver stands on the beac holding the bow, and talking to Albrecht.
(pressing Albrecht's hand) Goodbye.
May life be good to you both. As for the others В—В— they will be quiet here В—В— and I will be with them.
Albrecht smiles at Thea and Oliver. Oliver steps into the bow.. The servant shoves the boat off from the beach.
